title: Romney Assails Obama for Favoring Words Over Action
content:
CINCINNATI — Mitt Romney , seeking to overshadow an appearance by the president in Ohio on Thursday , mocked President Obama as a candidate of words , not deeds , whose eloquent speechmaking abilities have not been matched by the effectiveness of his economic policies .
Giving his own economic speech in the same state where Mr. Obama was presenting his , Mr. Romney said that the president ’ s re-election campaign felt compelled to deliver a major address on the economy “ because he hasn ’ t delivered a recovery for the economy . ”
“ Now , I know that he will have all sorts of excuses , and he ’ ll have all sorts of ideas he ’ ll describe about how he ’ ll make things better , ” Mr. Romney said . “ But what he says and what he does are not always the exact same thing . And so if people want to know how his economic policies have worked and how they perform , why they can talk to their neighbor and ask if things are better . ”
“ As you look at the president ’ s record , it is long on words and short on action that created jobs , ” Mr. Romney said during a speech here at a family-owned factory that manufactures industrial products .
Mr. Romney , whose staff hastily moved up the timing of his speech to beat Mr. Obama to the podium , assailed Mr. Obama ’ s health care overhaul , financial regulation , energy policies and approach to international trade agreements as hostile to businesses and obstacles to an economic recovery .
He called on Americans to judge the president on his record , not his rhetoric .
“ In my experience in thinking about people who I want to have work for me , whether it ’ s my doctor or the person that ’ s going to be painting the house , I want to make sure they do a good job the first time , ” he said . “ And if they didn ’ t , I want someone who can do a better job . ”
As he has in the past , Mr. Romney pledged to repeal the Affordable Care Act , pursue punitive trade policies against China and approve a pipeline that would carry oil to the United States from Canada , which the Obama administration has delayed .
“ If I have to build it myself to get it here , I ’ ll get that oil into America , ” Mr. Romney said of the pipeline .
The Romney campaign is seeking to portray Mr. Obama as increasingly out of touch with the harsh economic reality facing ordinary Americans , deploying a critique that Democrats have long made against Mr. Romney . Aides argue that Mr. Obama has opened himself to such a line of attack by declaring that the “ private sector is doing fine , ” a line that Mr. Romney has repeated , daily , for the past week in assailing the president .
On Thursday , his campaign issued its third advertisement featuring a clip of the president making the remark , which it juxtaposed with a litany of grim economic statistics and newspaper headlines . “ How can President Obama fix our economy , ” the ad asks , “ if he doesn ’ t understand it ’ s broken ? ”
